There are quite a few:

  1. Holy books
    Jews accept the Hebrew Bible (the Mesorah version) as their basic holy texts. Samaritans accept the Pentateuch only.
  2. Version of the Torah
    Jews and Samaritans use different versions of the Torah. The texts are similar, with many minor differences but a few very big ones, such as -
  3. Holy sites
    The Torah speaks of “the place that God will choose” (or, in the Samaritan version, “the place that God has chosen”). Jews believe these verses refer to Jerusalem, while Samaritans believe that they refer to Mt. Gerizim. The Samaritan Torah includes many verses that sanctify Mt. Gerizim as the site of God’s Temple - including an additional commandment in the Ten Commandments that speaks specifically about the sanctity of Mt. Gerizim
  4. Oral Torah
    Orthodox Judaism accepts the idea of the Oral Torah, a collection of oral traditions dating back to Moses that interpret and add on to the Written Torah. Books documenting the Oral Torah are the Mishna, Talmud and later commentaries on them. They are considered holy books within Judaism. Samaritans do not accept this doctrine or the idea that there are any other holy books besides the Pentateuch.
    Samaritans have their own books of commentaries, history and hymns written by Samaritan scholars over the centuries, but they do not ascribe to them holiness like the Torah.
  5. Role of Priests vs Rabbis
    After the destruction of the Second Temple in Jerusalem the role of Priests (Cohanim) in Judaism greatly diminished and Rabbis took on the role of the spiritual leadership of the Jewish people. Priests continue to serve as the religious leadership of the Samaritans, headed by the High Priest Ovadia ben Asher, considered to be the 134th generation directly descended from the High Priest Aaron, brother of Moses.

High Priest Ovadia, spiritual leader of the Samaritan community

I could go on and on writing about all the other minor differences between the two religions, such as differences in interpretation of Biblical commandments, the Passover sacrifice, the Jewish and Samaritan calendars, disagreements regarding historical or Biblical events, traditional clothing, the different versions of Hebrew and Aramaic used in the different communities and even political differences. But the question asks for only the main differences, so I will stop here.

Another question really for Wikipedia as it does seem a bit like reinventing the wheel so I'll be brief.

The Samaritans still exist, although there aren't many of them left, so you could have asked in the present tense.

The Samaritan religion resembles ancient pre-rabbinic Judaism. They only have the Torah (first five books) of the Jewish Bible and reject the rest. They take the Torah literally, similar to the Karaite and Ethiopian Jews.

A major difference between Jews and Samaritans is that Samaritans do not accept Jerusalem as the center of the faith but rather consider Mt. Gerizim in Nablus to be the true temple mount. They had a rival temple there for many centuries but it too was ultimately destroyed.

How do earthquake resistant buildings work?

If a building's foundation sits on soft or filled-in soil, the whole building may fail in an earthquake regardless of the advanced engineering techniques employed.

However, if the soil beneath a structure is firm and solid, engineers can greatly improve how the building-foundation system will respond to seismic waves by tying the foundation to the building so the whole structure moves as a unit.

Another technique-- known as base isolation -- involves floating a building above its foundation on a system of bearings, springs or padded cylinders. Usually lead-rubber bearings, which contain a solid lead core wrapped in alternating layers of rubber and steel are chosen for this purpose. The lead core makes the bearing stiff and strong in the vertical direction, while the rubber and steel bands make the bearing flexible in the horizontal direction. Bearings attach to the building and foundation via steel plates and then, when an earthquake hits, allow the foundation to move without moving the structure above it. As a result, the building's horizontal acceleration is reduced and suffers far less deformation and damage.

Even with a base-isolation system in place, a building still receives a certain amount of vibrational energy during an earthquake. The building itself can dissipate, or damp, this energy to some extent, although its capacity to do this is directly related to the ductility of the material used in the construction. Brick and concrete buildings have low ductility and therefore absorb very little energy. This makes them especially vulnerable in even minor earthquakes. Buildings constructed of steel-reinforced concrete, on the other hand, perform much better because the embedded steel increases the ductility of the material. And buildings made of structural steel offer the highest ductility, allowing buildings to bend considerably without breaking.

Installing damping systems is also an effective technique to protect the building from earthquakes. Active mass damping, for example, relies on a heavy mass mounted to the top of a building and connected to viscous dampers that act like shock absorbers. When the building begins to oscillate, the mass moves in the opposite direction, which reduces the amplitude of mechanical vibrations. It's also possible to use smaller damping devices in a building's brace system.

The Samartans that live in Israel today currently number at 820 people. They are not, nor have ever been Jewish. Their origins date back to Nebuchadnezar of Babylonia’s resetlement program. Where did the Samaritans in the Bible come from? Where are they now?

The term “Samaritans” first appeared in Scripture after the conquest of the ten-tribe kingdom of Samaria in 740 B.C.E.; it was applied to those who lived in the northern kingdom before that conquest as distinct from the foreigners later brought in from other parts of the Assyrian Empire. (2Ki 17:29)

It appears that the Assyrians did not remove all the Israelite inhabitants, for the account at 2 Chronicles 34:6-9 (compare 2Ki 23:19, 20) implies that during King Josiah’s reign there were Israelites still in the land.

The term “Samaritans” first appeared in Scripture after the conquest of the ten-tribe kingdom of Samaria in 740 B.C.E.; it was applied to those who lived in the northern kingdom before that conquest as distinct from the foreigners later brought in from other parts of the Assyrian Empire. (2Ki 17:29)

It appears that the Assyrians did not remove all the Israelite inhabitants, for the account at 2 Chronicles 34:6-9 (compare 2Ki 23:19, 20) implies that during King Josiah’s reign there were Israelites still in the land.

In time, “Samaritans” came to mean the descendants of those left in Samaria and those brought in by the Assyrians. Therefore some were undoubtedly the products of mixed marriages.

At a still later period, the name carried more of a religious, rather than a racial or political, connotation. “Samaritan” referred to one who belonged to the religious sect that flourished in the vicinity of ancient Shechem and Samaria and who held to certain tenets distinctly different from Judaism.​—Joh 4:9.

The Samaritan Religion. The development of the Samaritan religion was due to a number of factors, not the least of which stemmed from Jeroboam’s efforts at alienating the ten tribes from Jehovah’s worship as centered in Jerusalem.

For about 250 years after the nation had split into two kingdoms, the God-ordained Levitical priests were replaced by a man-appointed priesthood, which, in turn, led the kingdom of Israel in the practice of demoralizing idolatry. (1Ki 12:28-33; 2Ki 17:7-17; 2Ch 11:13-15; 13:8, 9)

From early times, the Scriptures of the Samaritans have consisted of only the first five books of the Bible, and these only in their own recension, written in their own characters and known as the Samaritan Pentateuch. The rest of the Hebrew Scriptures, with the possible exception of the book of Joshua, they rejected. The Samaritan Pentateuch differs from the Masoretic text in some 6,000 instances, most of which are minor.

However, some are major, as, for example, the reading of Deuteronomy 27:4, where Gerizim is substituted for Ebal, the place where the laws of Moses were to be inscribed on whitewashed stones. (De 27:8) The obvious reason for this change was to give credence to their belief that Gerizim is the holy mountain of God.

Today the nation or people are all but gone. You may find a few remaining descendants claiming to be of the Biblical Samaritans.

What was a Samaritan in the Bible?

Someone who lived in the city/state of Samaria.

Samaria in the oldest continuously inhabited city in the world. It is located in between what was the Old Testament nation of Israel in the south and nation tribe of Judah in the north.

Following the return of the Jews to Israel after the Babylonian Captivity (around 500 BC), any man who were married to non-Jewish women (and would not divorce them) were exiled from Israel and settle in Samaria and the region around. This was an attempt to keep the Jewish bloodline pure.

Someone who lived in the city/state of Samaria.

Samaria in the oldest continuously inhabited city in the world. It is located in between what was the Old Testament nation of Israel in the south and nation tribe of Judah in the north.

Following the return of the Jews to Israel after the Babylonian Captivity (around 500 BC), any man who were married to non-Jewish women (and would not divorce them) were exiled from Israel and settle in Samaria and the region around. This was an attempt to keep the Jewish bloodline pure.

Over time the Samaritans developed their own branch of the Jewish faith. They formed their own priesthood. Because they did not have access to the Temple in Jerusalem they set up alters for sacrifices by the well that Jacob had dug in Samaria and other sites associated with Abraham, Isaac and Jacob. They developed their version of the Mosaic Laws and rituals, etc. they became a rival to the orthodox Jewish religion.

Thus the question by the Samaritan woman to Jesus about whether people should worship in Jerusalem or at the well that Jacob had build. And why was the true Jewish religion.

As rivals, they were often portrayed as evil people and poorly treated by the Jews. That is why when Jesus wanted to make the point that anyone who needs help is our neighbor, he choose a Samaritan (who would normally have been an enemy to the Jews) to be the one who saved the man who had been beaten by robbers.

The bible nor Jesus ever condemned them. In fact Jesus used a Samaritan in His parable of the “Good Samaritan”. He also spoke to and witnessed to a Samaritan woman at the well, surprising her as she did not expect a Jewish man to talk to her.

Not like Arabic/Persian Invaders.

Arabic and Persian Invaders plundered and destroyed all the temples and looted the money while Hindu rulers plundered only the treasure in Palaces/Forts and destroyed only palaces and forts and cities but not temples .

But Hindu Kings used to Bring the Murthy of Gods and some sculptures without any damage from the defeated Kingdoms and installed the same in their Kingdom to prove the victory in front of the Kingdom subjects or to showcase the victory for ages to come!

Unlike Islam rulers who used the sculptures for other purposes but that's not the case of Hindu Kings.

Reinstalling Vigrahams or Murthies in some other place without destroying it is not considered as sin in Hinduism and even the plundered wealth of other kingdoms were used to construct the new temples!

This has happened in many instances.

Pallava Time

Pallavas were ruling from Kanchi which is now in Tamil Nadu and Pallavas were one of the strongest ruling kingdoms of that time who were known for their temple architecture and the famous Kings.

Vatapi Ganapathi( Badami as called now in Karnataka) which is in Tamil Nadu now , is believed to have been abducted from Vatapi and brought to the Tamil region by Paranjothi, a general in the army of the enemy Pallava king during one of the many battles fought between Chalukya and Pallava armies in the 7th century CE.

The icon is said to have been reinstalled in a small shrine in the Uthrapathisvaraswami temple complex in Tamil Nadu, later the same Paranjyothi becomes as Nayanmar or a Shaiva Saint.

The games Sanskrit sing “Vatapi Ganapathim" is composed praising the same Ganapthi my Muthuswami Dikshitar who lived and composed several centuries later in 18th century.

Now Narasimhavaraman in return constructs a Mallikarjuna temple at Vatapi with the same bounty to commemorate his victory, and took the title ‘Vatapi-Kondan’ or ‘taker of Vatapi’.

But some historians say this is myth , am not sure

Rich slice of history

Now let's go to same Chalukya Time-Chalukyas of Badami

Aihole near Badami has a Kailasanathar temple.

This temple resembles the kailasanathar temple of Kanchi. After defeating Pallavas, Vikramaditya Pulikesi took both his queens to Kanchipuram. They visited the Kailasanathar temple and wanted to construct a similar one in their town. The treasures from Kanchi were used to build the Kailasanathar temple of Aihole.

There are also 2 temples, names Lokeshwara temple and Trilokeshwara temple. Based on their wives names, lokamadevi (Lokeshwara) and Trilokadevi(Trilokeshwara).

One temple follows the Dravidian style vimana and the other one Nagara style vimana.

Now let's visit the great Cholas.

When Cholas defeated the Kadambas of Banavasi, they brought few Sculptures from these places.

In the sculpture of dwarabalagas,an Inscriptions of rathathiraja was found. This shares a information that this dwarabalagas, were taken from Karnataka, after burning the city of Banavasi.These statues were placed in darasuram temple earlier but now they are tranfered to the art gallery tanjore.

In one more instance.

When Cholas( Raja Raja Chola) won over the Chalukyas ,they used the treasure money to construct the Great Peruvudaiyar Temlple of Tanjavur.

It's also believed that the Shiva Lingam of Peruvidaiyar Temple is said to be brought from the Vemulavada Temple in the present Telangana region

In turn what did the Cholas do ,they have constructed hundreds of temples in the present Karnataka,Andhra and Telangana.

Samaria is the oldest continually inhabited city in the world. There have been people there since the Stone Age.

They were originally Canaanites, but then became part of the Hebrew nation. Though it retain a large non-Jews population. When there was a split between the northern kingdom (Israel) and the southern kingdom (Judea), Samaria became the capital of the Norther Kingdom. As such, they did not want their citizens going to Jerusalem (capital of Judea) to worship at the temple, so they developed their own branch of the Jewish faith, including copies of the Torah and other Jewish texts altered to support Samaria rather than Jerusalem as the center of the Jewish faith.

Following the Babylonian Captivity, under the scribe Ezra, the Jews rebuild Jerusalem and started to reclaim the rest of the nation. Ezra required than any man who had a Babylonian/Gentile wife to divorce them and send them away. He wanted to remove all Babylonian religious ideas from among the people. Anyone who would not divorce their wife was exiled to live in Samaria instead. It was technically across a border and other country at that time.

This division further the split between the Jews and the Samaritans (even though they were both descendants of Abraham through his son Isaac.) During the time of Jesus was there was a lot of hatred between the two groups.

That Jesus, in John 3, would have gone and preached to the Samaritans was shocking. And that he would actually have a conversation with one - especially a woman (at the well) - and that he would discuss religion to her was scandalous. (And she brought up the question about why Jews worshipped in Jerusalem when Abraham had lived in Samaria and offered sacrifices there.)

So the Samaritans where an off shoot of the Jews race that had their own version of “Judaism”. And where often at odds with the rest of the Jews community.

What is a samaritan?

Samaritans or Samaritan people are members of an ethnoreligious group originating from the Israelites of historical Israel and Judah. They are native to the Levant and adhere to Samaritanism, an Abrahamic, monotheistic and ethnic religion

Jews see it as the Temple Mount in Jerusalem.

B) Samaritans see only the 5 books of Moses as Holy Scriptures.

Jews have the entire Bible as Holy Scriptures.

C) Samaritans use the Hebrew language but with the Ketav Ivri Alphabet.

Somnath Temple is one of the ancient temples of India. It was looted, sabotaged many a times resulting in destruction. In 1026 AD, Mahmud Ghazni plundered this temple. Then came Ala-Ud-Din Khilji and then Aurangzeb. This temple, as per the history, was destructed as many as 17 times.

HISTORY: Destroyed and Reconstructed

This temple has been demolished and constructed so many times. Initially, this temple was destroyed by Ghurid emperor Qutb-ud-din Aibak and then this temple was rebuilt by a Gujarati merchant and then again this temple was destroyed during the rule of Sikandar Lodhi and then again in the reign of Mughal emperor Akbar this temple was reconstructed by Raja Man Singh and Raja Todar mal. But this was not the end of this story, it’s the turn of Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb who not only destroyed this temple but also constructs Gyanvapi Mosque in its place. Yes, there was a Samaritan temple on Mt Gerizim. The site was excavated starting in the early 1980’s and the temple dates probably to the 5th century BCE. The story according to Josephus is that it was destroyed sometime in the second century BCE and rebuilt, only to be destroyed again by Judean forces on orders of the Maccabean Yohanon Cohen Gadol, the Judean High Priest, before the beginning of the first century BCE. There was religious rivalry between Judeans and Samaritans, since Samaritans claimed Mt Gerizim was the site chosen by God for the binding of Isaac, rather than Mt Moriah in Jer

Yes, there was a Samaritan temple on Mt Gerizim. The site was excavated starting in the early 1980’s and the temple dates probably to the 5th century BCE. The story according to Josephus is that it was destroyed sometime in the second century BCE and rebuilt, only to be destroyed again by Judean forces on orders of the Maccabean Yohanon Cohen Gadol, the Judean High Priest, before the beginning of the first century BCE. There was religious rivalry between Judeans and Samaritans, since Samaritans claimed Mt Gerizim was the site chosen by God for the binding of Isaac, rather than Mt Moriah in Jerusalem. Also, the situation in those times was quite unsettled for independent Judea owing to incursions by the Seleucid Empire.

Archaeological Evidence for the First Stage of the Samaritan Temple on Mount Gerizim on JSTOR
Ephraim Stern, Yitzhak Magen, Archaeological Evidence for the First Stage of the Samaritan Temple on Mount Gerizim, Israel Exploration Journal, Vol. 52, No. 1 (2002), pp. 49-57
https://www.jstor.org/stable/27926987?read-now=1#page_scan_tab_contents
